title.narrative: Provide and extend life-saving WASH assistance to new IDPs, returnees and host communities of Rural Hama

description.narrative: Syria is facing an unprecedented destruction of water facilities and other services due to the war. Today, according to the 2018 HRP 13,1 million people are in need of assistance and 5,2 million of them are facing acute humanitarian needs. During the past 7 years, access became a challenge for humanitarian actors due to security reasons and administrative obstacles, especially in Rural Areas. Since the beginning of the crisis, Hama governorate has been affected by conflict and witnessed intensified fighting in the second half of 2017 up to recently. Since then, it has been underserved and includes numerous hard-to-reach areas. In terms of WASH, the most common source of drinking water for IDPs and host communities alike is water trucking, generally provided by the Water board. Indeed, in Hama governorate as a whole, 45% of the primary drinking water comes from water trucking, 30% from existing networks, 21% from closed or open well. 4% of the population is also drinking rainwater and water from the river. In addition, REACH findings revealed that 55% of assessed communities and IDPs are modifying hygiene practices to cope with a lack of water, which calls for hygiene awareness sessions. According to the assessment conducted by TGH and SARC staff in September 2018, the price of water in rural Hama varies from 1000 to 2000 Syrian pounds per m3 (while 1kg of bread costs 200 SYP), which entails additional burden for the families leaving in rural Hama, deprived of livelihoods and fallen into poverty due to the war and multiple displacements. Rural Hama has therefore been identified by TGH as relevant for an intervention addressing non-responded acute needs and potential new emergency needs in the coming months. The main findings of TGH need-based assessment led the Organization to propose a water and hygiene approach to respond to the most urgent needs in Harbanifse and Aqrab. The purpose of this project is to provide WASH assistance to under-served and hard-to-reach rural areas of Hama to 17.750 individuals, through combining life-saving and life sustaining humanitarian assistance (Wash facilities repairs, hygiene promotion and distribution of hygiene kits). With regards to the proximity of the targeted region with Idlib, the project has a contingency dimension, as it will benefit to potential new comers, beyond the immediate services it will provide to already identified beneficiaries. Noteworthy is that the project has been approved by SARC, which contributed to the definition of its contents.
